Issues.Title: Empty ListViewGroups are displayed in the Inspect tree
Issues.Body:
.NET Core Version:
- 6.0.100-preview.2.21155.3

Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:
- No (regression from #3224)
 
**Minimal repro:**

1. Create an app with a ListView
2. Add several ListViewGroup to the ListView
3. Add ListViewItem related to the first group to the ListView
4. Run the application
5. Run the Inspect

**Actual behavior**
Invisible (empty) ListViewGroups are displayed in the Inspect tree
![Issue-4779-actual](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/114397233-1f2fc480-9ba7-11eb-840e-113328d9cead.png)

**Expected behavior**
Invisible (empty) ListViewGroups should not be displayed in the Inspect tree
![Issue-4779-expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/114397246-23f47880-9ba7-11eb-8daf-641f3a7227dd.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Empty ListViewGroups are displayed in the Inspect tree" (#4779)

Issues.Body:
.NET Core Version:

Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:

**Minimal repro:**

Issues.Title: WinForms designer emits broken code in multi-targeted projects
Issues.Body:
VS 16.9, 16.10

**Summary**:

[See initial post here](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Winforms-designer-issue-with-ISupportIni/1392601?port=1025&fsid=da8f689d-711c-4ea9-bb1e-6825f9253bbe&entry=suggestion&space=8&scope=follow?port=1025&fsid=da8f689d-711c-4ea9-bb1e-6825f9253bbe&entry=suggestion&space=8&scope=follow&moreInfo=true&viewtype=all)

It's possible to create code which compiles, but then fails at runtime depending on which framework you edit a Form with in the designer.

**Steps to Reproduce**:

1. Create a simple WinForms app targeting .NET 5.
2. Update the project file to support multi-targeting .NET 3.5 and 4.7.2.  
3. Add a Split Container control to the form with the environment set to .NET5 or 4.72.
You will see the designer.cs contains statements like
            `((System.ComponentModel.ISupportInitialize)(this.splitContainer1)).BeginInit();`
4. Remove all unused 'using' statements so that the app will build on .NET 3.5 and 4.7.2
5. Modify Main to
```       
        static void Main()
        {
#if NET5_0_OR_GREATER
            Application.SetHighDpiMode(HighDpiMode.SystemAware);
#endif
            Application.EnableVisualStyles();
            Application.SetCompatibleTextRenderingDefault(false);
            Application.Run(new Form1());
        }
```
6. Run the app in environment .NET5 / 4.7.2 - works fine
7. Run the app in environment .NET35 - crashes
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/271656/114391882-f223e780-9b8f-11eb-9ea7-f00eb11d9896.png)

**Expected Behavior**:
Not to crash.

The entire Designer.cs is rewritten every time a change is made.  The problem is it's rewritten for the specific environment you're currently targeting in the designer.  The designer needs to emit conditional compilation statements and make best efforts to satisfy all targeted  environments. e.g.  for ISupportInitialize we should have
```
#if NET40_OR_GREATER
            ((System.ComponentModel.ISupportInitialize)(this.splitContainer1)).BeginInit();
#endif
```
Similarly for any other platform specific code.

**Actual Behavior**:
Crash.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WinForms designer emits broken code in multi-targeted projects" (#4780)

Issues.Title: .NET 5.0 is not rendering WinForms created in the .NET Framework 4.8 correctly
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: **.NET 5.0**
<!-- e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info` -->

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: **No**
<!-- Yes / No -->

**Problem description:**
.NET 5.0 is not rendering WinForms created in the .NET Framework 4.8 correctly:

![ISSUE](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8019466/114283721-8cb1e880-9a21-11eb-89f8-3faac20bd390.png)

<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.
  -->


**Expected behavior:** .NET 5.0 should render WinForms created in .NET Framework 4.8 with the same dimensions

**Step to reproduce this issue:** Copy a WinForm created in .NET Framework 4.8 (See: [LoginForm.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6290700/LoginForm.zip)) to a .NET 5.0 project and check how this WinForm is rendered.


**Minimal repro:** 100%

Issues.Title: Fix ANE in the "ListViewSubItemAccessibleObjectin" constructor (#4744) (port to 5.0)
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4742


## Proposed changes
- Added missing logic for adding and removing owner. The problem is reproduced because when getting an accessibility object for a `ListViewSubItem`, the `ListViewSubItem` may not have an owner. This is because we have several ways to create and add an unowned `ListViewSubItem` to an `ListViewItem`.
- Added/updated unit tests

## Customer Impact

An app crash upon clicking on a listview subitem.

* **Before fix:**
  ![Issue-4742-BeforeFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/113000113-34086300-9178-11eb-8378-4990c11449c8.gif)

* **After fix:**
  ![Issue-4742-AfterFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/113000176-3f5b8e80-9178-11eb-88d6-23780f2697b3.gif)

## Regression? 
- Yes

## Risk
- Minimal
## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->
- Unit tests

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->
- Microsoft Windows: Version 10.0.19041.388
- .NET Core SDK: 5.0.100

Issues.Title: Porting: Fixing missing 'TypeForwardedFrom' attribute
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4561 (a cherrypick of  #4715)


## Proposed changes

Padding is serialized in to Resx file and any serializable type that was 'TypeForwardedTo' should have 'TypeForwarededFrom' attribute to help is de-serialize it.
And also, we recently added dependency on this attribute, in core designer, while writing types in to Resx file.

## Customer Impact

Any resource file that has Padding serialized will fail to load it while de-serializing the type for the application. This attribute was missed while moving this type from System.Windows.Forms.dll

## Regression? 

- Yes from .NET core 3.1 and .NET framework.

## Risk

None

Issues.Title: Native portions of winforms controls are not updating their Font correctly in HDPI scenarios.
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
Net 6.0

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Problem description:**
Some of the native portions in Winforms controls ( ex: Tabtitle in 'TabPage' or 'ColumnHeader' in ListView  or 'ListItem' in ListBox) are not updating their Font when there is a change DPI.

Explicit WM_SETFONT message is not helping update the Font but something between Managed Font and Native Font seems not working as expected. See below example ( in Control class scope).

Snippet 1:

```cs
                IntPtr hwndHdr = User32.SendMessageW(this, (User32.WM)LVM.GETHEADER);
                if (hwndHdr != IntPtr.Zero)
                {                   
                    User32.SendMessageW(new HandleRef(this, hwndHdr), User32.WM.SETFONT, (IntPtr)FontHandle, PARAM.FromBool(false));
                 }
                 var snippet1Font = Font.FromHfont((IntPtr)FontHandle);
```

snippet 2:
```cs
                IntPtr hwndHdr = User32.SendMessageW(this, (User32.WM)LVM.GETHEADER);
                if (hwndHdr != IntPtr.Zero)
                { 
                    var local = Properties.GetObject(s_fontProperty);
                    if (local is null)
                    {
                        Properties.SetObject(s_fontProperty, Font);
                    }                  
                    User32.SendMessageW(new HandleRef(this, hwndHdr), User32.WM.SETFONT, (IntPtr)FontHandle, PARAM.FromBool(false));
                   var snippet2Font = Font.FromHfont((IntPtr)FontHandle);
                 }
```

In both cases, Font from 'Fonthandle' evaluates to same (i.e snippet1Font.equals(snippet2Font)  evaluates to '**true**')

**Expected behavior:**
Result from code snippet 2 above.

**Minimal repro:**

Any windows from app with above listed controls and DPi awareness set to 'PerMonitorV2'. Drag the winforms application from One DPI setting monitor to the other.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36968667/113607096-adcba100-95fd-11eb-9e84-ec6ed5aa6c91.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Native portions of winforms controls are not updating their Font correctly in HDPI scenarios." (#4762)

Issues.Title: Fix incorrect behavior of ListViewSubItem
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4679 


## Proposed changes
- Changed the logic for getting `ListViewSubItems` for the Inspector tree: 
  * Now they are not displayed for `List`, `SmallIcon`, `Large` views.
  * For `Tile` view, we display the `ListViewSubItems` in the Inspector  tree based on the number of `ListViewSubItems`, the number of `ListViewColumns` and the `Bounds` property, through which we know that the `ListViewSubItem` is visible.
  * For `Details` view, we display `ListViewSubItems` based on the number of `ListViewColumns`. If the cell is visible and the `ListViewSubItems`  does not exist, we create a fake `ListViewSubItemsAccessibleObject` for that cell.
- Fixed the issue with getting a rectangle for `ListViewSubItem` when the `ListView` is in `Tile` view
- Added missing conditions
- Added unit and MAUI tests

## Customer Impact
<details>
<summary> Details view </summary>

**Before fix:**
![Issue-46749_before_Details](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/113559134-88449480-9609-11eb-9b30-0d70878b76b2.png)

**After fix:**

</details>

<summary> List view </summary>

**Before fix:**
![Issue-46749_before_List](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/113559245-b1fdbb80-9609-11eb-814f-5c9143d9ca2f.png)

**After fix:**

Issues.Title: Fixing MonthCalendar accessibility tree
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4224

## Proposed changes

- Added a UI test app for testing a MonthCalendar control. 
- Remove all previous accessible objects implementations to create and set up MonthCalendar accessible objects from scratch. It is necessary for comfortable testing and review.
- Implement all MonthCalendar accessible objects with correct properties and actions. Add unit tests.
- Add a documentation described expected MonthCalendar accessible objects properties and actions depending on the calendar view. It is necessary for comfortable review, testing and implementing future fixes.


## Customer Impact

- Fixed incorrect accessibility properties of MonthCalendar items.
- MonthCalendar items are accessible in multi-calendar mode.


## Regression? 

- No


## Risk

- Minimal


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

- A MonthCalendar accessible object is correct only for one-month mode. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/113393004-b4101200-939e-11eb-8f51-0bdb38f55725.png)



### After

- All visible MonthCalendar items are accessible
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/113391163-c50b5400-939b-11eb-863e-698a5255d8d6.png)



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing
- Unit tests
- CTI


## Accessibility testing

- Using Inspect, Narrator and AccessibilityInsights


## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- .NET SDK Version: 6.0.100-preview.1.21101.5
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19042.867]

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator rectangle can't  focus on the entire context of RichTextBox contorl when setting  the RightToLeft property as true
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
.NET 6.0.100-preview.4.21181.20

**More info:**
1.  The issue can't reproduce on TextBox & ComboBox controls.
2.  This is not a regression issue, also can reproduce on .NET SDK 3.1 & 5.0.
3. Narrator can announce the entire context of RichTextBox contorl correctly, fixed in GH issue [3455](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/3455).

**Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:** 
 Yes 

**Problem description:**
Can't see the rectangle for RichTextBox contorl when setting the RightToLeft property as true.

**Expected behavior:**
Narrator rectangle can  focus on the entire context of RichTextBox contorl when setting the RightToLeft property as true.

**Actual behavior:**
Narrator rectangle can't  focus on the entire context of RichTextBox contorl when setting property the RightToLeft as true
![CoreNewIssue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/113266521-f3d7ea80-9307-11eb-8a66-b8ef02effa40.gif)


**Minimal repro:**
1. Extract the application. [WinFormsApp4.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6242165/WinFormsApp4.zip).
2. Build and run it.
3. Open the Narrator tool, and press the Tab keyboard to focus the contorl one by one.
4. Observe the narrator rectangle for RichTextBox contorl which setting the RightToLeft property as true.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Narrator rectangle can't  focus on the entire context of RichTextBox contorl when setting  the RightToLeft property as true" (#4754)
